required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Assessment of Dose Effectiveness of Vitamin D Supplementation During Pregnancy- a Dose Comparison Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Dose Effectiveness of Vitamin D Supplementation During Pregnancy

brief_summary.textblock: The study is randomized blinded trial of Vitamin D supplementation to pregnant women; the study participants will receive Vitamin D in supplement form. Pregnant women will be individually randomized to three groups receiving a dose of 400, 2000 and 4000 IU/ day till the time of delivery.A blood sample will also be collected from the participant at the time of recruitment /before the starting of the supplementation for the assessment of Calcium, Phosphorus, Alkaline Phosphatase and Vitamin D levels. The second blood sample for vitamin D level to assess vitamin D status will be done after completion of the supplementation phase at the time of delivery (till 48 hours of delivery). The samples will be sent to Aga Khan University laboratory

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators hypothesize that Pakistani mothers as darkly pigmented, will require substantially higher oral supplementation with vitamin D to replenish the micronutrient stores and aid to resolve associated maternal and neonatal morbidity due to Vitamin D deficiency. The investigators expect that if vitamin D is supplemented to pregnant women, their newborn infants would inevitably replenish the micronutrient stores and aid to resolve the maternal and neonatal morbidity due to Vitamin D deficiency.This is hospital based double blinded trial, study participants divided into three groups which will receive Vitamin D supplementation in 400, 2000 and 4000 International Units. The group which will receive 400 IUs will be treated as control group.

primary_outcome.description: Hypovitaminosis, Pre eclampsia, Preterm labour, preterm birth, low birth weight, Still birth rates.

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of vitamin D deficiency in pregnant women
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal vitamin D deficiency in the target group.

arm_group.description: Arm 1 is receiving vitamin D supplementation in 2000 IU/day ,
Arm 2 is receiving vitamin D supplementation in 4000/IU per day
Arm 3 is receiving vitamin D supplementation in 400 IU/day

intervention.description: comparison of different dosages of vitamin D
comparison of different dosages of vitamin D Supplement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women aged 15 - 45 years
- Less than 16 weeks pregnant from Last menstrual period.
- Agree to take part in this study, will be enrolled.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women with pre existing type 1 or type II diabetes,
- Pregnant women with pre existing hypertension
- Women with multiple fetuses, babies (twins, triplets)
- Women with fetal anomaly in scan
- Refuse to participate in the study

results_reference.citation: Farrant HJ, Krishnaveni GV, Hill JC, Boucher BJ, Fisher DJ, Noonan K, Osmond C, Veena SR, Fall CH. Vitamin D insufficiency is common in Indian mothers but is not associated with gestational diabetes or variation in newborn size. Eur J Clin Nutr. 2009 May;63(5):646-52. doi: 10.1038/ejcn.2008.14. Epub 2008 Feb 20.
